Award.AwardTitle: Core Activities of the Committee on Science, Engineering and Public Policy (COSEPUP)
Award.AbstractNarration: The National Academy of Science Committee on Science, Engineering and Public Policy (COSEPUP) is charged to "to deliberate on initiatives for new studies in the area of science and technology policy, taking especially into account the concerns and requests of the President's Science Advisor, the Director of the NSF, the Chairman of the National Science Board, and the chairmen of key science and technology-related committees of the Congress." Its work has addressed issues of critical importance to Federal Agencies and the Nation. Key issues that COSEPUP is currently addressing or has recently addressed include maintaining the excellence of human resources for U.S. science and engineering research, promoting effective management of U.S. federal research investments, and ensuring research integrity and the responsible conduct of research. Since its inception, the National Science Foundation has supported COSEPUP activities. This award will provide funds for core support of COSEPUP, to continue its work as an independent advisor on issues relating to national science and technology policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Committee on Science, Engineering, and Public Policy of the National Academy of Sciences, National Academy of Engineering, and Institute of Medicine is composed of leaders in all sectors of the research community who are committed to providing guidance to government officials and legislators on a wide range of policy concerns related to science, engineering, and medicine. All participants are members of NAS, NAE, or IOM. The three presidents are ex officio members, as are at least two members of each of the governing councils.

 

The committee conducts its work through consensus studies by experts, workshops that enable experts to present and discuss their ideas, and direct interactions between committee members and federal officials. During the term of this grant, the committee published the consensus report "The Postdoctoral Experience Revisited," which examined how well postdoctoral training programs are preparing the next generation of scientists and engineers and how well the postdoctoral system meshes with the operations of the overall research enterprise. The report was well received and catalyzed a number of regional meetings organized by universities as well as a number of activities organized by graduate students and postdocs. COSEPUP convened a working group of representatives of federal research agencies and scientific professional societies to follow up on implementation of the report's recommendations.

 

The committee also published a summary of a workshop held in September 2013 on "The Arc of an Academic Research Career," which examined important career stress points--career entry, the tenure decision, and retirement--in an effort to not only understand the nature of these stress points, but also to see how policies and practices at each point affect the other points. The committee also engaged in direct conversations with national leaders such as presidential science adviser John Holdren and National Science Foundation director France Cordova as well as staff of key congressional committees and education leaders wrestling with the challenge of new educational technologies and new delivery systems such as massive online open courses (MOOCs).

 

The committee also launched an effort to develop a mechanism more timely and focused advice to policymakers. Problems often emerge suddenly and require rapid response. In such cases, the National Academies deliberative process might not be appropriate. COSEPUP is therefore designing a system that will make it possible to produce short "action memos" that are based on previous National Research Council consensus studies and that include only the information necessary to help a policymaker facing a specific decision. The committee is working on memos that address current concerns related to workforce training, support for basic research, scientific integrity and reliability, cybersecurity, early career scientists, and vaccines.

 

The committee is also ready to craft new approaches to meet circumstances. When science adviser John Holdren told the committee that he was concerned about how new federal travel restrictions could impede the participation of government scientists in professional conferences, COSEPUP decided that the best approach would be to draft a letter to the director of the Office of Management and Budget to explain the critical role that government scientists play in the work of the research enterprise and why their attendance at professional meetings is so valuable.
